newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - March 25.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - March 25.

text.p: These are the leading stories in the South African press on Tuesday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
BUSINESS DAY

- Education Minister Sibusiso Bengu has launched a new curriculum for South African schools, which has eight new learning areas and steers away from rote learning and the external assessment of pupils.

- The labour department has proposed that employers be required to pay a training levy of 1.0 to 1.5 percent of their payrolls to a national fund which would finance skills development of workers, potential employees and budding entrepreneurs.

- South Africa is set to be integrated into the European Union's main trade arrangement, the Lome Convention, next month after Spain agreed to back down on a threat to block South Africa's accession to the convention.
- Zairean rebels have been offering gold mining concessions in areas under their control to foreign companies, an investment analyst said.
BUSINESS REPORT
- Labour Minister Tito Mboweni has proposed a payroll levy of between 1.0 and 1.5 percent on companies to fund a national training programme.
- Premier Foods intends to close down several plants in a bid to cut huge overcapacity and improve inefficiency, Ian Heron, a director at the Premier Group, confirmed.
- Insurance industry officials called for the complete deregulation of commissions paid to insurance brokers, and for the total disclosure of the charges clients pay for financial services.
- The parliamentary portfolio committee on finance registered "extreme concern" at the slow pace at which the government was moving to give parliament a bigger say in the budget.

- Employee benefits have been transformed over the past few years by a quiet revolution, driven by collective bargaining and changing company policy, a according to a survey by industrial relations consultancy Andrew Levy and Associates.
SAKE-BEELD
- The government wants to impose a levy of 1.0 to 1.5 percent on company payrolls to pay for a skills development strategy.

- A new era has begun in relations between South Africa and Namibia, with the signing of an official agreement between the two countries on the scrapping of 1.24 billion rand of Namibian debt by South Africa.

- Spain is dropping its veto which was to prevent South Africa joining the Lome Convention, paving the way for membership of the European Union's most important trade agreements with developing countries.
BEELD

- The South African Rugby Football Union (SARFU) kept secret test results which showed several South African rugby players used forbidden drugs. The former head of SARFU's committee on forbidden drugs said the players -- mainly at club level, but including some playing for the provinces -- were allowed to continue without any disciplinary steps being taken against them.
THE STAR
- Education Minister Sibusiso Bengu has unveiled a new school curriculum which will encourage pupils to develop at their own pace.

- Gauteng provincial police commissioner Sharma Maharaj has ordered an investigation into proposals by residents and businesses in Johannesburg's Sandringham suburb to open a private police station in the area.

- The Shobashobane Christmas Day massacre of 18 villagers in KwaZulu-Natal in 1995 was clearly a politically motivated attack by the Inkatha Freedom Party on the African National Congress, Judge Hillary Squires found.
